channel.title: Stories from theguardian.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best theguardian.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: How Did Ellen DeGeneres Become One Of The Biggest Villains Of 2020?
item.description: Recently, and not for the first time, the comedian's public persona has appeared to be at odds with her private actions.

item.title: Why Is 'Cottagecore' Booming?
item.description: The visual and lifestyle movement is designed to fetishize the wholesome purity of the outdoors.

item.title: The Rise Of Zoom Breakups
item.description: The search for love continues — and so does the ending of once-promising relationships. Now, though, all this is happening via videoconference.

item.title: The Eerie Silence Of The Las Vegas Strip, In Photos
item.description: The empty strip, shut down for the first time since the JFK assassination, shows the striking toll the coronavirus crisis has taken on fun and leisure.

item.title: How Coronavirus Almost Brought Down The Global Financial System
item.description: The crisis has brought the economy to a near halt, and left millions of people out of work. But thanks to intervention on an unprecedented scale, a full-scale meltdown has been averted — for now.

item.title: A Tale Of Two New Yorks: Pandemic Lays Bare A City's Shocking Inequities
item.description: The coronavirus has laid bare two societies divided on lines of class and race: a divide reflected in skewed death figures.

item.title: The WHO Vs. Coronavirus: Why It Can't Handle The Pandemic
item.description: Attacked by Trump and ignored by many of its most powerful members, the World Health Organization is facing a major crisis — just at the moment we need it most.

item.title: Veterinary Scientist Hailed For Faroe Islands' Lack Of COVID-19 Deaths
item.description: Debes Christiansen adapted his salmon-testing lab to test for disease among humans.

item.title: 'The Impossible Has Already Happened': What Coronavirus Can Teach Us About Hope
item.description: In the midst of fear and isolation, we are learning that profound, positive change is possible.

item.title: Hydroxychloroquine: How An Unproven Drug Became Trump's Coronavirus 'Miracle Cure'
item.description: With help from Fox News and Elon Musk, a misleading French study prompted a wave of misinformation that made its way to the president.

item.title: Oceans Can Be Restored To Former Glory Within 30 Years, Say Scientists
item.description: Major review reports recovery of marine life, but a redoubling of efforts is still needed.

item.title: Polyamory In A Pandemic: Who Do You Quarantine With When You're Not Monogamous?
item.description: Coronavirus is forcing people in poly relationships to make tough choices about who to be intimate with.

item.title: The Wondrous Life And Mysterious Death Of Golden Eagle 1703
item.description: Golden eagles are one of the most protected species in the US — so what happens when one turns up dead in a field?

item.title: 'We Can't Go Back To Normal': How Will Coronavirus Change The World?
item.description: The long read: Times of upheaval are always times of radical change. Some believe the pandemic is a once-in-a-generation chance to remake society and build a better future. Others fear it may only make existing injustices worse

item.title: One Man's Role In A 6,000-Mile Run Through North America
item.description: When Noé Álvarez joined an extraordinary ultramarathon he tested himself physically and mentally, while also connecting with his heritage.

item.title: The Best Chat Apps For Your Coronavirus Quarantine
item.description: Group video platforms are making a heroic rise from last resort to daily routine as people stay indoors. We tried five of the most popular ones out there.

item.title: 50 Works That Changed Our Critics' Lives
item.description: Our reviewers select standout moments in their field which still shape their love of the arts.

item.title: How Spring Can Make Us Healthier And Happier
item.description: Longer, lighter days can help us banish old habits, sleep better and improve our mental health, even during the lockdown.

item.title: Growing Up With The World's Biggest Stars, By Their Children
item.description: The sons and daughters of John Wayne, John Lennon, Caitlyn Jenner and others tell us what it was like to grow up with a world-famous parent.

item.title: The Missing Six Weeks: How Trump Failed The Biggest Test Of His Life
item.description: The president was aware of the danger from the coronavirus - but a lack of leadership has created an emergency of epic proportions.

item.title: 'It's A Razor's Edge We're Walking': Inside The Race To Develop A Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: Around the world, more than 40 teams are working on a vaccine for COVID-19. We followed one doctor in the most urgent quest of his life

item.title: How Did Spain Get Its Coronavirus Response So Wrong?
item.description: Spain saw what happened in Iran and Italy - and yet it just overtook China's death toll in one of the darkest moments in recent Spanish history.
item.kicker: AND THE WORST IS YET TO COME

item.title: The Unlisted: How People Without An Address Are Stripped Of Their Basic Rights
item.description: Without a street address you have no access to credit or bank accounts, a pension or voting rights. But large parts of the world's population still live off the map

item.title: UK Coronavirus Mass Home Testing To Be Made Available 'Within Days'
item.description: The test is to be validated this week, then made available to healthcare workers and general public.

item.title: Coronavirus Death Toll In Spain Overtakes China As Lockdowns Extend Across Globe
item.description: Spain records 738 deaths in past 24 hours, while death toll in Italy now double that of Hubei.

item.title: 'I Was Completely Unprepared': Confronting My Sister's Death
item.description: Despite my father's job as a funeral director, and my career studying death and dying, personal loss still floored me.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics To Be Postponed To 2021 Due To Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Japan's prime minister, Shinzo Abe, will propose a one-year postponement for the Tokyo Olympics during talks with IOC president, Thomas Bach.

item.title: The Weird, Audacious Heists Of Hotel Room Thieves
item.description: They're putting the average shoplifter to shame by taking paintings and mattresses. How do they get away with it?
item.kicker: THIS MATTRESS? NOT WHAT IT LOOKS LIKE

item.title: California Power Company Pleads Guilty To Manslaughter In Paradise Fire
item.description: PG&E pleads guilty to criminal charges in the deadly 2018 fire and will pay about $3.5m in fines.

item.title: What Happens To People's Lungs If They Get COVID-19?
item.description: Respiratory physician John Wilson explains the range of Covid-19 impacts, from no symptoms to severe illness featuring pneumonia.

item.title: Can Computers Ever Replace The Classroom?
item.description: With 850 million children worldwide shut out of schools, tech evangelists claim now is the time for AI education. But as the technology's power grows, so too do the dangers that come with it.

item.title: The Tech Execs Who Don't Agree With 'Soul-Stealing' Coronavirus Safety Measures
item.description: "In the absolutely worse case, the overall life expectancy worldwide would click down by a few weeks," one CEO wrote. he added. "Instead of 79.60 years to live we would have 79.45 years to live."

item.title: How Helsinki And Oslo Cut Pedestrian Deaths To Zero
item.description: After years of committed action, neither city recorded a single pedestrian fatality in 2019.

item.title: When Will A Coronavirus Vaccine Be Ready?
item.description: Human trials will begin in April — but even if they go well, there are many barriers before global immunisation is feasible

item.title: Real Estate For The Apocalypse: My Journey Into A Survival Bunker
item.description: Not long ago, I traveled to the Black Hills of South Dakota to see the place from which humanity would supposedly be reborn after global civilisational collapse.

item.title: Ohio Primary Vote Halted At Last Minute Amid Coronavirus Court Battle
item.description: Health officials step in after judge refuses Governor's recommendation to postponing in-person voting.

item.title: No News Is Good News: German 'Big Brother' Contestants Unaware Of Pandemic
item.description: Some of the last people in the world to find out about the rapid spread of Covid-19 are a group of 14 men and women sitting in a house in Cologne, western Germany.

item.title: Research Finds Huge Impact Of Interventions On Spread Of Covid-19
item.description: A study suggests that the number of cases could have been cut by 66% if China had acted a week earlier.

item.title: The Inside Story Of The Millennium Dome And A (Not So) Total Disaster
item.description: Even before it opened at the dawn of the year 2000, London's Millennium Dome had become a byword for failure. But two decades on, it could be time for a reassessment.
item.kicker: THE ROOF IS NOT ON FIRE

item.title: How The Killing Of An Abusive Father By His Daughters Fueled Russia's Culture Wars
item.description: The notorious case of three teenage sisters inspired a campaign for change - and a backlash from the patriarchy

item.title: Before And After: Coronavirus Empties The World's Busiest Spaces
item.description: Aerial images reveal impact of outbreak on famous holy sites and capital cities

item.title: Dubai Ruler Organized Kidnapping Of His Children, UK Court Rules
item.description: Court also backs claim of Princess Haya that her husband Sheikh Mohammed intimidated her.

item.title: The Invisible City: How A Homeless Man Built A Life Underground
item.description: After decades among the hidden homeless, Dominic Van Allen dug himself a bunker beneath a public park. But his life would get even more precarious.

item.title: Texas Closes Hundreds Of Polling Sites, Making It Harder For Minorities To Vote
item.description: Guardian analysis finds that places where black and Latino population is growing by the largest numbers experienced the majority of closures and could benefit Republicans.

item.title: What We Can Learn From The Town That Dodged The 1918 Spanish Flu
item.description: In late 1918 the world's greatest killer — Spanish flu — roared towards Gunnison, a mountain town in Colorado.

item.title: Inside Delhi: Beaten, Lynched And Burnt Alive
item.description: The violence raged across the north-east of India's capital for four days as mosques were set alight, Muslims were burned alive in their homes or dragged out into the streets and lynched.

item.title: How Work Stole Our Weekends
item.description: Our forebears struggled hard for the right to a work-life balance. But now our leisure time is under unparalleled assault. It's time to renew the fight.
item.kicker: CAN'T SLACK WHEN YOU'RE ON SLACK

item.title: 'People Don't Get It': Inside The World Of Hyper-Realistic Baby Doll Collecting
item.description: A subculture of lifelike baby dolls is thriving on social media — despite enthusiasts being dismissed as grown women playing mommy

item.title: The 29-Year Old At The Heart Of Trump's 'Deep State' Purge
item.description: Johnny McEntee, an ex-college quarterback, heads a sweeping White House effort to purge the civil service and install loyalists.

item.title: Extreme Selfies: The Photographer Who Goes Out On A Limb
item.description: Arno Rafael Minkkinen has been using his body as his subject for five decades. His images — never manipulated or retouched — are surreal, spiritual and transformative.
